items.title: Food banks stretched thin amid government shutdown
items.standfirst: A pair of federal judges ruled that the Trump administration must tap into a contingency fund to continue making payments for SNAP, which was set to have its funding expire. Still, some food banks are already struggling to keep up with demand. Kati Weis reports.
items.content: A pair of federal judges ruled that the Trump administration must tap into a contingency fund to continue making payments for SNAP, which was set to have its funding expire. Still, some food banks are already struggling to keep up with demand. Kati Weis reports.

items.title: Instacart, DoorDash and other companies offer discounts to SNAP recipients

items.title: Trump administration blocked from suspending Snap benefits for millions of Americans
items.standfirst: One judge issued temporary restraining order while another judge ruled the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income householdsUS politics live – latest updatesTwo federal judges issued back-to-back rulings on Friday in separate cases ordering the Trump administration to use contingency funds to continue paying for food stamps during the government shutdown.A federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday afternoon blocked the Trump administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans, in a case brought by a group of US cities, non-profit organizations and a trade union. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Federal judges order administration to pay SNAP benefits but what's next remains unclear
items.standfirst: Two federal judges ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funding to provide SNAP benefits. But it's unclear how much, or when, those funds would be provided before the funding runs dry.
items.content: Two federal judges ordered the Trump administration to use emergency funding to provide SNAP benefits. But it's unclear how much, or when, those funds would be provided before the funding runs dry. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

items.title: A judge to weigh in on SNAP benefits. And, Trump wants to resume nuclear testing
items.standfirst: A federal judge is set to decide whether the Trump administration will have to find funds to keep SNAP benefits flowing. And, President Trump says the U.S. should resume nuclear weapons testing.
items.content: A federal judge is set to decide whether the Trump administration will have to find funds to keep SNAP benefits flowing. And, President Trump says the U.S. should resume nuclear weapons testing.(Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo)

items.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: US Senate votes to reject Trump’s global tariffs on more than 100 countries
items.standfirst: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...
items.content: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump directs Pentagon to match Russia and China in nuclear weapons testing
items.standfirst: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: Tanzania President Hassan wins disputed election amid deadly protests
clusters.neutral_headline: Tanzania President Hassan Wins Disputed Election

items.title: Tanzania President Hassan wins disputed election amid deadly protests
items.standfirst: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan won a landslide election victory, official results showed Saturday. The opposition Chadema party, barred from taking part in the poll, said that hundreds of people have been killed by security forces since protests broke out on election day on Wednesday.
items.content: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan won a landslide election victory, official results showed Saturday. The opposition Chadema party, barred from taking part in the poll, said that hundreds of people have been killed by security forces since protests broke out on election day on Wednesday.

items.title: Tanzania’s Hassan declared landslide winner in election that triggered violent protests
items.standfirst: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...
items.content: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Election triggered days of violent protests after main rivals were excluded from presidential race.
items.content: Election triggered days of violent protests after main rivals were excluded from presidential race.

ai_summary: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the election with a landslide victory.
The opposition Chadema party was barred from participating in the election.
Hundreds of people were reportedly killed during election protests.
Hassan received over 97% of the vote, according to official results.
The election triggered days of violent protests across Tanzania.

clusters.title: UN Security Council supports Morocco’s plan for Western Sahara
clusters.neutral_headline: UN Supports Morocco's Plan for Western Sahara

items.title: UN Security Council supports Morocco’s plan for Western Sahara
items.standfirst: The resolution supports Morocco's claim to the disputed Western Sahara, a stance backed by Trump's administration.
items.content: The resolution supports Morocco's claim to the disputed Western Sahara, a stance backed by Trump's administration.

items.title: UN Security Council backs Moroccan plan for disputed Western Sahara
items.standfirst: The UN Security Council approved a US-backed resolution on Friday supporting Morocco's continued control of the disputed Western Sahara, saying that "genuine autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty" could well be the most "feasible" option for the mineral-rich territory. The Algerian-backed Polisario Front continues to advocate independence for the former Spanish colony.
items.content: The UN Security Council approved a US-backed resolution on Friday supporting Morocco's continued control of the disputed Western Sahara, saying that "genuine autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty" could well be the most "feasible" option for the mineral-rich territory. The Algerian-backed Polisario Front continues to advocate independence for the former Spanish colony.

items.title: UN approves resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to Western Sahara
items.standfirst: Move is strongest endorsement yet for retained rule over disputed territory, despite fierce opposition from AlgeriaThe UN security council has approved a US-backed resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to the disputed Western Sahara, despite fierce opposition from Algeria.Although Friday’s vote was divided, the resolution offers the strongest endorsement yet for Morocco’s plan to keep sovereignty over the territory, which also has backing from most European Union members and a growing number of African allies. Continue reading...
items.content: Move is strongest endorsement yet for retained rule over disputed territory, despite fierce opposition from AlgeriaThe UN security council has approved a US-backed resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to the disputed Western Sahara, despite fierce opposition from Algeria.Although Friday’s vote was divided, the resolution offers the strongest endorsement yet for Morocco’s plan to keep sovereignty over the territory, which also has backing from most European Union members and a growing number of African allies. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The UN Security Council approved a resolution supporting Morocco's claim.
The resolution backs Morocco's continued control of Western Sahara.
The resolution suggests "genuine autonomy" as a feasible option.
The Polisario Front continues to advocate for independence.
The resolution was backed by the US.

clusters.title: Hand of Moscow? The men jailed for vandalism in French hybrid warfare case
clusters.neutral_headline: Bulgarians Jailed for Vandalism in French Hybrid Warfare Case

items.title: Hand of Moscow? The men jailed for vandalism in French hybrid warfare case
items.standfirst: Three Bulgarians are jailed for painting red hands on France's Holocaust Memorial in a suspected case of Russian "destabilisation".
items.content: Three Bulgarians are jailed for painting red hands on France's Holocaust Memorial in a suspected case of Russian "destabilisation".

items.title: Alleged Russian-linked hate attacks in France "are a double blow to those targeted"
items.standfirst: Three Bulgarian men are on trial in Paris for alleged involvement in spray-painting blood-red hands on the city's Holocaust Memorial, with courts expected to give their verdict. French intelligence services link the act of vandalism to a campaign by Russia to destabilise France and other Western societies. FRANCE 24's Shirli Sitbon went to the trial and tells us more about the importance of this case.
items.content: Three Bulgarian men are on trial in Paris for alleged involvement in spray-painting blood-red hands on the city's Holocaust Memorial, with courts expected to give their verdict. French intelligence services link the act of vandalism to a campaign by Russia to destabilise France and other Western societies. FRANCE 24's Shirli Sitbon went to the trial and tells us more about the importance of this case.

ai_summary: Three Bulgarians were jailed for painting red hands on France's Holocaust Memorial.
The vandalism is suspected to be linked to Russian destabilization efforts.
French intelligence services connect the act to a Russian campaign.
The court is expected to give its verdict on the case.
The case highlights alleged Russian-linked hate attacks in France.

items.title: Meta Defies AI Spending Gloom With Record-Breaking Bond Sale

items.content: Meta Platforms Inc. found record-shattering demand for its bond sale on Thursday even as its shares plunged, in a sign that bond investors are looking past any concerns about its artificial-intelligence spending plans.

ai_summary: Investors in listed companies are demanding financial returns.

clusters.title: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future
clusters.neutral_headline: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future:

items.title: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future
items.standfirst: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor has been stripped of his remaining royal titles in the wake of mounting scandals over his relationship with late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse against the two men. The former prince was no longer listed on the official roll of the peerage as of Friday.
items.content: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor has been stripped of his remaining royal titles in the wake of mounting scandals over his relationship with late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse against the two men. The former prince was no longer listed on the official roll of the peerage as of Friday.

items.title: King Charles to remove Prince Andrew's titles and eject him from the Royal Lodge
items.standfirst: Britain's Prince Andrew will have his royal titles formally removed and will move out of his home in Windsor, Buckingham Palace said Thursday, as the royal faces growing pressure over his ties to the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein
items.content: Britain's Prince Andrew will have his royal titles formally removed and will move out of his home in Windsor, Buckingham Palace said Thursday, as the royal faces growing pressure over his ties to the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein

ai_summary: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor lost his royal titles.
He was removed from the official roll of the peerage.
The removal followed scandals related to Jeffrey Epstein.
He will be removed from his home in Windsor.
Buckingham Palace announced the removal of his titles.

clusters.title: Israel confirms identities of hostages' bodies returned by Hamas

items.title: Israel confirms identities of hostages' bodies returned by Hamas
items.standfirst: The bodies were identified as those of Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch, the Israeli prime minister's office said.
items.content: The bodies were identified as those of Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch, the Israeli prime minister's office said.

items.title: Hamas hands over bodies of two Israeli hostages amid fragile Gaza truce
items.standfirst: Remains of Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch returned to Israel for burial after identification process, Israeli military saidHamas handed over two bodies of deceased Israeli hostages on Thursday, a day after the tenuous Gaza ceasefire was shaken by deadly Israeli strikes across the strip.The bodies of the hostages Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch were returned to Israel for burial after an identification process was completed, the Israeli military said late on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Remains of Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch returned to Israel for burial after identification process, Israeli military saidHamas handed over two bodies of deceased Israeli hostages on Thursday, a day after the tenuous Gaza ceasefire was shaken by deadly Israeli strikes across the strip.The bodies of the hostages Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch were returned to Israel for burial after an identification process was completed, the Israeli military said late on Thursday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hamas returned the bodies of two Israeli hostages.
The bodies were identified as Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch.
The Israeli prime minister's office confirmed the identities.
The bodies were returned for burial.
